Imbalanced nucleotide metabolism leads to age- and mtDNA-dependent inflammatory responses and senescence-associated secretory phenotype in senescence.
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09541-7 Imbalanced nucleotide metabolism leads to age- and mtDNA-dependent inflammatory responses and senescence-associated secretory phenotype in senescence.

title: Diverging fish biodiversity trends in cold and warm rivers and streams
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09556-0

In the past three decades, fish abundance, richness and uniqueness have diverged across cold and warm streams, and the effects on native fish communitie…
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09556-0 In the past three decades, fish abundance, richness and uniqueness have diverged across cold and warm streams, and the effects on native fish communities of stream warming and increases in introduced fishes have magnified each other.

title: Volcanic crisis reveals coupled magma system at Santorini and Kolumbo
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09525-7

Seismological and geodetic data are used together with a machine learning earthquake catalogue to reconstruct magma migration before and during the 2025…
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09525-7 Seismological and geodetic data are used together with a machine learning earthquake catalogue to reconstruct magma migration before and during the 2025 volcano–tectonic crisis at Santorini volcano, indicating a coupling between Santorini and Kolumbo.

title: Design of facilitated dissociation enables timing of cytokine signalling
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09549-z

A fresh approach to protein design that incorporates excited intermediate states enables precise control over the lifetime of protein interactions, with…
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09549-z A fresh approach to protein design that incorporates excited intermediate states enables precise control over the lifetime of protein interactions, with potential applications in cell-signalling modulation and in biosensors and synthetic circuits.

title: Collective homeostasis of condensation-prone proteins via their mRNAs
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09568-w

The authors discover a homeostatic process termed interstasis, in which an increased concentration of proteins within RNA–protein condensates induces th…
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09568-w The authors discover a homeostatic process termed interstasis, in which an increased concentration of proteins within RNA–protein condensates induces the sequestration of their own mRNAs.

title: Proximal cooperative aerial manipulation with vertically stacked drones
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09575-x

A cooperative aerial manipulation system, called FlyingToolbox, can work stably with sub-centimetre-level docking accuracy under vertical-stack flight c…
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09575-x A cooperative aerial manipulation system, called FlyingToolbox, can work stably with sub-centimetre-level docking accuracy under vertical-stack flight conditions.

title: Isothermal solidification for high-entropy alloy synthesis
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09530-w

Gallium is used as a sacrificial agent and mixing medium for the isothermal solidification synthesis of high-entropy alloy nanomaterials with diverse cr…
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09530-w Gallium is used as a sacrificial agent and mixing medium for the isothermal solidification synthesis of high-entropy alloy nanomaterials with diverse crystallinities and morphologies.

title: Systematic discovery of CRISPR-boosted CAR T cell immunotherapies
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09507-9

CELLFIE, a CRISPR platform for optimizing cell-based immunotherapies, identifies gene knockouts that enhance CAR T cell efficacy using in vitro and in v…
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09507-9 CELLFIE, a CRISPR platform for optimizing cell-based immunotherapies, identifies gene knockouts that enhance CAR T cell efficacy using in vitro and in vivo screens.

title: Reprogramming neuroblastoma by diet-enhanced polyamine depletion
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09564-0

Enhanced polyamine depletion in neuroblastoma models decreases translation of mRNA codons with adenosine in the third position, reprogramming the tumour…
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09564-0 Enhanced polyamine depletion in neuroblastoma models decreases translation of mRNA codons with adenosine in the third position, reprogramming the tumour proteome away from cell cycle progression and towards differentiation.

title: A haplotype-based evolutionary history of barley domestication
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09533-7

The evolutionary history of barley is analysed using ancient and modern DNA.
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09533-7 The evolutionary history of barley is analysed using ancient and modern DNA.

title: The formation and propagation of human Robertsonian chromosomes
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09540-8

Analysis of human Robertsonian chromosomes originating from 13, 14 and 21 reveal that they result from breaks at the SST1 macrosatellite DNA array and r…
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09540-8 Analysis of human Robertsonian chromosomes originating from 13, 14 and 21 reveal that they result from breaks at the SST1 macrosatellite DNA array and recombination between homologous sequences surrounding SST1.

title: Protecting double Holliday junctions ensures crossing over during meiosis
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09555-1

Conditional ablation experiments show that key components of the synaptonemal complex protect double Holliday junction recombination intermediates to en…
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09555-1 Conditional ablation experiments show that key components of the synaptonemal complex protect double Holliday junction recombination intermediates to ensure their resolution into crossover products, which are required for accurate chromosome segregation during meiosis.

title: In vivo CRISPR screens identify modifiers of CAR T cell function in myeloma
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09489-8

In vivo loss-of-function CRISPR screens were performed to identify genes influencing CAR T cell persistence and function in human multiple myeloma, high…
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09489-8 In vivo loss-of-function CRISPR screens were performed to identify genes influencing CAR T cell persistence and function in human multiple myeloma, highlighting CDKN1B as a promising target.

title: Low-overhead transversal fault tolerance for universal quantum computation
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09543-5

Logical operations can be performed fault-tolerantly with only a constant number of syndrome extraction rounds for a broad class of quantum error correc…
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09543-5 Logical operations can be performed fault-tolerantly with only a constant number of syndrome extraction rounds for a broad class of quantum error correction codes, including the surface code with magic state inputs and feedforward, to achieve ‘transversal algorithmic fault tolerance’.

title: Engineered enzymes can suppress genome-editing errors
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03071-y

Genome editors are molecular machines that can rewrite the genetic code in cells, but sometimes they produce errors in the form of unintended sequence i…
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03071-y Genome editors are molecular machines that can rewrite the genetic code in cells, but sometimes they produce errors in the form of unintended sequence insertions or deletions, collectively known as indel errors. Genome editors have now been engineered that make up to 60-fold fewer indel errors than previous ones did.

title: Climate change is reshaping fish communities in the United States
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02826-x

Rising temperatures and the introduction of non-native fishes have been linked to rapid changes in fish communities across the United States.
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02826-x Rising temperatures and the introduction of non-native fishes have been linked to rapid changes in fish communities across the United States.

title: Arousal reframed as an organism‑wide dynamic system
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03067-8

The temporal evolution of a hidden, low-dimensional and organism-wide process, inferred from measuring the pupil of an eye, has been shown to account fo…
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03067-8 The temporal evolution of a hidden, low-dimensional and organism-wide process, inferred from measuring the pupil of an eye, has been shown to account for complex spatio-temporal patterns of brain activity over timescales of seconds. This points to an underlying dynamic that continuously structures the unfolding of brain, body and behavioural variables.

title: The future of universities: a Nature special report
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03086-5

The world’s universities are under intense pressure. Nature examines the threats they face and asks how the sector can and must adapt to survive.
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03086-5 The world’s universities are under intense pressure. Nature examines the threats they face and asks how the sector can and must adapt to survive.

title: Using short synthetic nucleic acids to probe genes in viruses that infect bacteria
summary:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03074-9

Earth’s most diverse biological entities are the viruses that infect bacteria, called bacteriophages (phages). They are rich resources for discovering p…
body: Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03074-9 Earth’s most diverse biological entities are the viruses that infect bacteria, called bacteriophages (phages). They are rich resources for discovering proteins and tools for biotechnology, but many phage–bacteria systems resist genetic manipulation. Silencing phage genes in a non-genetic way with short synthetic nucleic acids offers a solution.
